ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Knowledge of early music, learned the tenor recorder, got to perform Spanish style music.
This course teaches you both ensemble and individual skills in what is most likely a new instrument or type of singing.
How to perform early music.
I learned how to sing in Spanish in a choir context.
I learned how to play an ancient instrument

Through performing beautiful pieces of early music, I learned new languages, vocal techniques, and compositional methods that will inform my approach to any music in the future.  Professor Herreid makes this course incredibly fun and engaging from insightful lectures about tuning to explaining the different types of early musical instruments.  For students interested in vocal performance, this is truly a must take class at Yale.
A deeper understanding of early period music (in particular Spanish Renaissance music) and performance in an ensemble setting
I learned so much about the periods we were performing music from, and I gained a lot of sight reading skills and felt like I really expanded my range.
The performance of Spanish Renaissance music. Learned how to play the violone, a baroque string instrument (most comparable to a modern cello).
Sight reading, new instrument, some music-related history.

I learned about early music history and performance, particularly the music of Renaissance Spain. I learned to play the viola da gamba, an instrument that I had never played before. I collaborated with a variety of musicians including singers, other viol players, recorder players, and more.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Grant is a great professor and fosters a really friendly, fun environment in the classroom! I loved making music with him and my peers this semester!

Strengths: Very chill class, Grant is a pleasure to perform under, participate in Yale Collegium, learn a new instrument
Weaknesses: none
This was an excellently structured course, and Professor Grant Herreid makes the class incredibly rewarding and entertaining as well.
It was such a wonderful time to sing and make music with everyone! There werent any weaknesses per se.

The course is fantastic in covering a wide variety of music in a short amount of time.  This does require adequate sight singing ability, but that makes the performance incredibly rewarding.  The music is beautiful, the professor is funny, and the students are talented.  This class is relaxing yet interesting, a rare balance at Yale.

Strengths: very interactive, with the ensemble setting and engagement between the instrumental and choral sections.
Weaknesses: none to note!

I thought this course had mostly strengths -- I loved the structure of classes and wish we had been able to perform in a concert setting, but I think we did the best with what we could do given COVID conditions!
This is a great course that needs no improvement. It brings early music to the masses of students, which is a mission that is very near and dear to my heart.

Strengths: this course is very well-taught. Students get to play beautiful, rare music and instruments, an experience that is difficult to find elsewhere. The workload is super low and every class is very enjoyable--an opportunity to get together with other musicians in the Yale community and make incredible music. Grant is a great leader for the group and incredibly knowledgeable about this music and time period. All the lectures/non-performance aspects of the class were incredibly informative and aided us in improving our performances. I got to learn the viola da gamba, a beautiful instrument that I probably could not have learned elsewhere. Weaknesses: none! (take this class.)

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! This is a great class to add if you need another credit or want to make some music in a low-key environment.
Yes, this course is great as a chill class for a musically inclined student. You get to learn a new instrument without having the stress of harsh grading.
Yes. Professor Herreid is a wonderful professor and is always looking for more ways to engage students! I wish I could take this class more than twice!
Yes! Early music is such a delight.
Yes I would. Prof Herreid is very nice and the class is fun and relaxing
Absolutely! It was such a great class to de-stress :)
Absolutely!

I would certainly recommend this course to another student.  The music is engaging, Prof. Herreid is so funny and understanding, and the material is genuinely interesting.  I learned new things about music after years of intense study, and I now approach all music I perform very differently.  Professor Herreid teaches you how to enhance your musical expression.  Also, the course is very manageable workload-wise.  There is almost no homework.
Absolutely! This course is amazing if you want to learn about earlier period music and also want to have some practical experience participating in a musical ensemble.
YES
Yes, great and unique class you can probably only take at Yale.
I definitely would! this is an excellent class that really helped me grow as a musician

I would. To take this course, you need to be somewhat musically inclined, but if you are, I would definitely take it. As Yale undergraduates, we have the rare opportunity to play baroque instruments in order to play early music authentically. It is a very rare thing to think, "I want to take up the theorbo!" (or the lute, or the viola da gamba, or the recorder, or the harpsichord, etc.) and simply be able to do it. This is a type of music that I personally find beautiful and compelling, and so if you can take this class, you should.
Yes!

If you play an instrument and are at all interested in music history, this is class that you must take during your time at Yale. Playing Renaissance instruments and music is a great opportunity that you will likely not find elsewhere. The class requires little commitment beyond showing up every week and performing with the group. Grant is a great professor--super flexible and knowledgeable about the material.

extras.title: MUSI 240 01 - The Performance of Early Music
